19.37: Keep all My Laws and do all that I tell you. I am the Lord.’”

20.2: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘Any man of Israel or of the strangers living in Israel, who gives any of his children to the false god Molech, must be put to death. The people of the land will kill him with stones.
20.3: I Myself will go against that man and he will not be numbered among God’s people, because he has given some of his children to Molech, making My holy place sinful and bringing shame on My holy name.
20.4: If the people of the land close their eyes when a man gives any of his children to Molech, and do not put him to death,
20.5: then I Myself will go against that man and his family. They will not be numbered among God’s people, and all who follow him to sell themselves to Molech.
20.6: ‘I will go against the person who turns to those who speak with bad spirits and talk to the dead. In doing this, he sells himself to them. He will not be numbered among God’s people.
20.7: So you should set yourselves apart and be holy. For I am the Lord your God.
20.8: Keep My Laws and live by them. I am the Lord Who sets you apart.
20.9: ‘If there is anyone who curses his father or mother, he will for sure be put to death. Because he has cursed his father or mother, his blood will be on his own head.
20.10: ‘If a man does sex sins with another man’s wife, even his friend’s wife, both the sinful man and woman must be put to death.
20.11: If a man lies with his father’s wife, he has put his father to shame. Both of the guilty ones must be put to death. They will suffer for their own sin.
20.12: If a man lies with his daughter-in-law, both of them must be put to death. They have done a bad sex sin. They will suffer for their own sin.
20.13: If a man lies with a male as if he were a woman, both of them have done a very sinful act. They must be put to death. They will suffer for their own sin.
20.14: If a man marries a woman and her mother, it is sin. Both he and they will be burned with fire, so this kind of sin will not be among you.
20.15: If a man lies with an animal, he must be put to death. Kill the animal also.
20.16: If a woman goes near any animal to have sex with it, you must kill the woman and the animal. They must be put to death. They will suffer for their own sin.
20.17: ‘If a man takes his sister, his father’s or mother’s daughter, and he sees her without clothes on and she sees him, it is a shame. They will be punished in front of their people. He has taken off his sister’s clothes. He will suffer for his own sin.
20.18: If a man lies with a woman who has a flow of blood, and takes her clothes off, he has made her flow to show. And she has shown the flow of her blood. So both of them will not be numbered among God’s people.
20.19: Do not take the clothes off your mother’s sister or father’s sister. For that is putting to shame one of your own family. They will suffer for their own sin.
20.20: If a man lies with the wife of his father’s or mother’s brother, he has put to shame his father’s or mother’s brother. They will suffer for their own sin. They will die without children.
20.21: If a man takes his brother’s wife, it is sin. He has put his brother to shame. They will have no children.
20.22: ‘Keep all My Laws and do what I tell you, so the land where I am bringing you to live will not spit you out.
20.23: Do not follow the ways of the nation which I am driving out before you. For they did all these things, and so I hated them.
20.24: But I have said to you, “Their land will belong to you. I Myself will give it to you for your own, a land flowing with milk and honey.” I am the Lord your God, Who has set you apart from all other peoples.
20.25: You are to know the difference between the clean animal and the animal that is unclean, and between the clean bird and the bird that is unclean. Do not make yourselves a sinful people with animal or bird or anything that moves on the ground, which I have set apart from you as being unclean.
20.26: Be holy to Me, for I the Lord am holy. I have divided you from the nations, so you belong to Me.
20.27: ‘A man or woman who speaks with bad spirits or who talks to the dead must be put to death. They will be killed with stones. They will suffer for their own sin.’”

21.1: The Lord said to Moses, “Say to the religious leaders, the sons of Aaron, ‘No one should make himself unclean for a dead person among his people,
21.2: except for his own family, his mother, father, son, daughter and brother,
21.3: or his young sister who is near to him because she has had no husband. For her he may make himself unclean.
21.4: He should not make himself unclean as a husband among his people, and so make himself sinful.
21.5: They should not cut all the hair from any part on their heads, or cut part of the hair off their face, or make cuts in their flesh.
21.6: They should be holy to their God and not put the name of their God to shame. For they give the gifts by fire to the Lord, the bread of their God. So they must be holy.
21.7: They should not take a woman who is unclean because of selling the use of her body. They should not take a woman who is divorced from her husband. For the religious leader is holy to his God.
21.8: So you must set him apart, for he gives the bread of your God. He will be holy to you. For I, the Lord Who sets you apart, am holy.
21.9: If the daughter of any religious leader makes herself sinful by selling the use of her body, she puts her father to shame. She will be burned with fire.
21.10: ‘The head religious leader on whose head the holy oil has been poured, and who has been set apart to wear the clothing, must not take the covering off his head or tear his clothes.
21.11: He must not go near any dead person or make himself unclean even for his father or mother.
21.12: He must not go out of the holy place or sin against the holy place of his God. For the crown of the holy oil of his God is on him. I am the Lord.
21.13: He should take a wife who has never had a man before.
21.14: He should not marry a woman whose husband has died, or a divorced woman, or one who has made herself sinful by selling the use of her body. But he should marry a woman from his own people, who has never had a man.
21.15: By doing this he will not sin against his children among his people. For I am the Lord Who makes him holy.’”
21.16: Then the Lord said to Moses,
21.17: “Say to Aaron, ‘None of your children or their children who has something wrong with his body should go near to give the bread as a gift to his God.
21.18: For no one whose body is not perfect should come near, no blind man, or man who cannot walk, or one with a marked face, or a bad arm or leg,
21.19: or a man who has a broken foot or hand,
21.20: or a man with a crooked upper back from birth, or a very little man, or one who has a bad eye or skin trouble or sores, or one whose sex parts have been crushed.
21.21: No man among the children of Aaron the religious leader, who has something wrong with his body, should come near to give the Lord’s gifts by fire. He should not come near to give the bread of his God, because he has something wrong with him.
21.22: He may eat the bread of his God, both of the most holy and of the holy.
21.23: But he should not come near the curtain or the altar, because he has something wrong with him, and so he may not sin against My holy places. For I am the Lord Who makes them holy.’”
21.24: So Moses spoke to Aaron and to his sons and to all the people of Israel.

22.2: “Tell Aaron and his sons to be careful with the holy gifts that the people of Israel set apart for Me. So they will not sin against My holy name. I am the Lord.
22.3: Say to them, ‘If any one of all your children comes near the holy gifts that the people of Israel set apart for the Lord, while he is unclean, he will be cut off from My holy place. I am the Lord.
22.4: None of the children of Aaron who has a bad skin disease or something flowing from his body may eat of the holy gifts until he is clean. If one touches anything that is unclean because of a dead body, or has had his seed come from his sex part,
22.5: or touches anything that is unclean that moves on the ground, or touches any man who makes him unclean, for whatever reason,
22.6: the man who touches any such thing will be unclean until evening. He must not eat of the holy gifts unless he has washed his body in water.
22.7: When the sun has gone down, he will be clean. After that he may eat of the holy gifts, for they are his food.
22.8: He should not eat an animal that dies of itself or is killed by wild animals. He will be unclean if he does. I am the Lord.
22.9: The religious leaders must obey My Law, so they will not be sinful because of it and die because they sin against My Law. I am the Lord Who makes them holy.
22.10: ‘But no one who is not a religious leader may eat the holy gift. One who is visiting the religious leader or working for him must not eat of the holy gift.
22.11: But a person whom the religious leader buys to work for him with his own money may eat of it. And those who are born in his house may eat of his food.
22.12: If a religious leader’s daughter is married to a man who is not a religious leader, she must not eat of the holy gifts.
22.13: But if a religious leader’s daughter loses her husband by death or divorce, and has no child and returns to her father’s house as when she was young, she may eat of her father’s food. But no stranger may eat of it.
22.14: If a man eats a holy gift by mistake, he must add a fifth of its worth to it and give the holy gift to the religious leader.
22.15: The religious leaders must not make the holy gifts unclean that the people of Israel give to the Lord.
22.16: This would bring sin upon them when they eat their holy gifts. For I am the Lord Who makes them holy.’”
22.17: Then the Lord said to Moses,
22.18: “Say to Aaron and to his sons and to all the people of Israel, ‘When any man of the house of Israel or of the strangers in Israel gives his gift for a burnt gift to the Lord, to pay a promise or as a free-will gift
22.19: to please the Lord, it must be a male that is perfect from the cattle, sheep or goats.
22.20: Do not give anything that is not perfect, for you will not please the Lord.
22.21: When a man gives a peace gift to the Lord to keep a special promise or for a free-will gift from the cattle or the flock, it must be perfect to be received. It must have nothing wrong with it.
22.22: You must not give to the Lord or make a gift by fire on the altar to the Lord any animals that are blind or broken or hurt or have a flowing sore or a skin disease.
22.23: You may give for a free-will gift a bull or lamb which has some part too long or too short. But it will not be received if it is to pay a promise.
22.24: Do not give to the Lord any animal with its sex parts hurt or crushed or torn or cut. Do not give such animals on the altar in your land.
22.25: And do not receive such animals from a man from another land to give as the food of your God. For they are unclean. They are not perfect. They will not be received from you.’”
22.27: “When a bull or sheep or goat is born, it must stay seven days with its mother. After that it will be received as a gift by fire to the Lord.
22.28: But do not kill a cow or female sheep and her young on the same day.
22.29: When you give thanks to the Lord by giving a gift in worship, give it the right way so you will be received.
22.30: It must be eaten on the same day. Do not leave any of it until morning. I am the Lord.
22.31: “So keep My Laws and obey them. I am the Lord.
22.32: Do not sin against My holy name. I will be honored among the people of Israel. I am the Lord Who makes you holy.
22.33: I brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord.”

23.2: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘These are the special suppers of the Lord, which you will keep for holy meetings. These are My special suppers.
23.3: Work may be done for six days. But the seventh day is the Day of Rest, a holy meeting when you do no work at all. It is the Day of Rest to the Lord in all your homes.
23.4: ‘These are the special suppers of the Lord, the holy meetings you will keep at the right times.
23.5: On the fourteenth day of the first month in the evening begins the Lord’s religious gathering to remember how His people left Egypt.
23.6: On the fifteenth day of the same month is the Lord’s special supper of bread without yeast. For seven days you will eat bread made without yeast.
23.7: On the first day you will have a holy meeting. You will not do any hard work.
23.8: But you will give a gift by fire to the Lord for seven days. On the seventh day is a holy meeting. You will not do any hard work.’”
23.9: Then the Lord said to Moses,
23.10: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘When you come into the land I am going to give you and gather its grain, bring some of the first fruits of your grain to the religious leader.
23.11: He will wave the grain before the Lord for you to be received. The religious leader will wave it on the day after the Day of Rest.
23.12: On the day when you wave the grain, you will give a perfect, one year old male lamb as a burnt gift to the Lord.
23.13: The grain gift with it will be one-fifth part of a basket of fine flour mixed with oil. It is a gift by fire to the Lord for a pleasing smell. And the drink gift with it will be a jar of wine.
23.14: Do not eat bread or dry grain or new grain until this same day, when you have brought the gift to your God. It is to be a Law forever for all your people in all your homes.
23.15: ‘Number seven full weeks from the day after the Day of Rest, from the day when you give the grain for the wave gift. There will be seven whole Days of Rest.
23.16: Number fifty days to the day after the seventh Day of Rest. Then give a new grain gift to the Lord.
23.17: Bring from your homes two loaves of bread for a wave gift, made of one-fifth part of a basket of fine flour. They will be made with yeast, as first-fruits to the Lord.
23.18: With the bread give seven one year old male lambs that are perfect, and one young bull, and two rams. They will be a burnt gift to the Lord, with their grain gift and their drink gift. It is a gift by fire with a pleasing smell to the Lord.
23.19: Then give one male goat for a sin gift and two male lambs one year old for a peace gift.
23.20: The religious leader will wave them with the bread of the first-fruits as a wave gift before the Lord, with the two lambs. They will be holy to the Lord for the religious leader.
23.21: On this same day call together a holy meeting. Do no hard work. It is a Law forever in all your homes for all your people.
23.22: ‘When you gather the food of your land, do not pick all the way to the corners of your field. And do not gather the food that falls. Leave it for those in need and the stranger. I am the Lord your God.’”
23.24: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘On the first day of the seventh month, you will have a Day of Rest. It will be a day of remembering, made known by the blowing of horns, a holy meeting.
23.25: Do not do any hard work. But give a gift by fire to the Lord.’”
23.26: Then the Lord said to Moses,
23.27: “The tenth day of this seventh month is the day to be made free from sin. It will be a holy meeting for you. You will be without pride and give a gift by fire to the Lord.
23.28: “Do no work on this day. For it is a day to be made free from sin, to be made free from your sin before the Lord your God.
23.29: If there is any person who will not be free from his pride on this day, he will be kept away from his people.
23.30: Whoever does any work on this day, I will destroy from among his people.
23.31: Do no work at all. It is a Law forever for all your people in all your homes.
23.32: It will be a Day of Rest for you. And you must be without pride. You will keep your Day of Rest from evening until evening on the ninth day of the month.”
23.34: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘On the fifteenth day of this seventh month is the special supper of tents to the Lord. It will last seven days.
23.35: A holy meeting will be on the first day. Do no hard work of any kind.
23.36: Give a gift by fire to the Lord for seven days. On the eighth day have a holy meeting and give a gift by fire to the Lord. It is a special gathering. Do no hard work.
23.37: ‘These are the special suppers, the holy meetings you will keep at the right times. They will be for giving to the Lord gifts by fire, burnt gifts and grain gifts, gifts of animals and drink gifts, each on its own day.
23.38: These are to be added to the Days of Rest of the Lord, and your gifts, both those that are promised and your free-will gifts that you give to the Lord.
23.39: ‘On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, when you have gathered the food of your land, you will have the special supper of the Lord for seven days. The first day and the eighth day will be Days of Rest.
23.40: On the first day, you will take the leaves of beautiful trees, branches of trees with big leaves and of trees beside the river. And be full of joy before the Lord your God for seven days.
23.41: You will keep it as a special supper to the Lord seven days in the year. It will be a Law forever for all your people. You will have it in the seventh month.
23.42: You will live in tents for seven days. All who were born in Israel will live in tents.
23.43: So all your people to come may know that I had the people of Israel live in tents when I brought them out of the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.’”
23.44: So Moses made known to the people of Israel the special suppers of the Lord.

24.2: “Tell the people of Israel to bring you pure oil from beaten olives for the light to keep a lamp burning all the time.
24.3: Outside the curtain of the Law in the meeting tent, Aaron will keep it burning from evening to morning before the Lord always. It will be a Law forever for all your people.
24.4: He will take care of the lamps on the pure gold lamp-stand before the Lord all the time.
24.5: “Then take fine flour and bake twelve loaves of bread. Use two jars of flour for each loaf.
24.6: Set them side by side in two rows, six in each row, on the pure gold table before the Lord.
24.7: Put pure, sweet-smelling spices on each row to go with the bread as something to be remembered. It is a gift by fire to the Lord.
24.8: Every Day of Rest he will set it before the Lord all the time. It is a Law forever for the people of Israel.
24.9: The bread is for Aaron and his sons who will eat it in a holy place. It is a most holy part for him out of the gifts by fire to the Lord. It is his share forever.”
24.10: Now the son of an Israelite woman, whose father was an Egyptian, went among the people of Israel. And the Israelite woman’s son and a man of Israel fought with each other among the tents.
24.11: The son of the Israelite woman swore against the name of the Lord. So they brought him to Moses. (His mother’s name was Shelomith, the daughter of Dibri, of the family of Dan.)
24.12: And they kept him shut up until the will of the Lord might be made known to them.
24.13: Then the Lord said to Moses,
24.14: “Take the one who has sworn against Me away from the tents. Let all who heard him lay their hands on his head. Then let all the people kill him by throwing stones.
24.15: Say to the people of Israel, ‘If anyone swears against his God, he will suffer for his own sin.
24.16: The one who speaks against the name of the Lord will be put to death for sure. All the people will kill him with stones. Both the stranger and those born in the land will be put to death when he speaks against the name of the Lord.
24.17: ‘If a man takes the life of any human being, he will be put to death for sure.
24.18: The one who takes the life of an animal will pay for it, a life for a life.
24.19: If a man hurts his neighbor, it will be done to him just as he has done,
24.20: broken bone for broken bone, eye for eye, tooth for tooth. Just as he has hurt a man, so he will be hurt.
24.21: So the one who kills an animal will pay for it with an animal. But the one who kills a man will be put to death.
24.22: You will have the same Law for the stranger and for the one born among you. For I am the Lord your God.’”
24.23: Then Moses spoke to the people of Israel. And they took the one who swore against God and brought him away from the tents and killed him with stones. So the people of Israel did as the Lord told Moses.

25.1: The Lord said to Moses at Mount Sinai,
25.2: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘When you come to the land I will give you, then the land will have a Year of Rest to the Lord.
25.3: Six years you will plant seeds in your field. Six years you will take care of your vines and gather their fruit.
25.4: But the seventh year will be a Year of Rest for the land, a Year of Rest to the Lord. You will not plant seeds in your field or take care of your vines.
25.5: You will not gather what grows of itself in your field. And do not gather the fruit of the vines that have not been cared for. The land will have a Year of Rest.
25.6: During the Year of Rest the land will give food for you, for your men and women servants, the man you pay to work for you, and the stranger who lives with you.
25.7: Even your cattle and the animals in your land will have food to eat.
25.8: ‘You are to number seven Years of Rest for yourself, seven times seven years. The time of the seven Years of Rest will be forty-nine years.
25.9: Then let the horn be heard on the tenth day of the seventh month. On the day to be made free from sin you will let a horn be heard all through your land.
25.10: You will honor the fiftieth year as holy. And let it be known in all the land that all who are living there are free. It will be a happy time for you. Each of you will return to what is his. Each will return to his family.
25.11: That fiftieth year will be a happy time for you. You will not plant seeds in the field, or gather the food that grows of itself, or gather fruit from the vines that are not cared for.
25.12: This is a happy time. It will be holy to you. You will eat from what the field gives.
25.13: ‘In this Year of Jubilee each one will have what was his.
25.14: If you sell anything to your neighbor, or buy from your neighbor, do not do wrong to one another.
25.15: You will pay your neighbor by the number of years since the Year of Jubilee. And he will sell to you by the number of years the food may be gathered.
25.16: You will make the price more if there are many years, and make the price less if there are few years. For he is selling you the food that is gathered each year.
25.17: Do not do wrong to one another, but fear your God. I am the Lord your God.
25.18: ‘So keep My Laws and do what I say, and you will be safe living in the land.
25.19: Then the land will give its food, so you can eat all you want and be safe living there.
25.20: If you say, “What will we eat in the seventh year if we do not plant seeds or gather in the food of our field?”
25.21: I will let My good come upon you in the sixth year, so it will give you enough food for three years.
25.22: When you are planting seeds in the eighth year, you can still eat from the old store of food. You can eat the old food until the food of the ninth year is gathered.
25.23: ‘The land will not be sold to be kept forever. For the land is Mine. You are only strangers staying with Me.
25.24: For all the land you have, you must be willing to let it go.
25.25: When your brother becomes poor and sells some of his land, then one in his family who is near to him is to come and buy what his brother has sold.
25.26: But a man may have no one to buy his land, and he himself may become able to buy it again.
25.27: Then he should add up the years since he sold it, and pay what is left of the price to the man to whom he sold it. So he will return to his own land.
25.28: But if he is not able to buy it again for himself, then what he has sold will belong to the one who bought it until the Year of Jubilee. In the Year of Jubilee it will be let go and he may return to it.
25.29: ‘If a man sells a house within the walls of a city, he has the right to buy it back for a whole year from the time he sold it. He can buy it during that year.
25.30: But if it is not bought back again for him within a whole year, then the house within the city walls belongs forever to the family of the one who bought it. It will not be returned to him in the Year of Jubilee.
25.31: But houses in towns that have no walls will be thought of as open fields. They may be let go, and will be returned in the Year of Jubilee.
25.32: The houses in the cities of the Levites may be returned to the Levites at any time.
25.33: If a house is not bought again by a Levite, then the house that was sold in one of their cities will be returned to him in the Year of Jubilee. For the houses of the Levites belong to them among the people of Israel.
25.34: But the open field of their cities must not be sold. It belongs to them forever.
25.35: ‘If your brother becomes poor and is not able to pay you what he owes, then you should help him as you would help a stranger or visitor. So he may live with you.
25.36: Do not make him pay for the use of the money he owes you. But fear your God, so your brother may live with you.
25.37: Do not make him pay for the use of your money or your food.
25.38: I am the Lord your God, Who brought you out of the land of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan and to be your God.
25.39: ‘If your brother becomes so poor that he sells himself to you, do not make him work as a servant.
25.40: He will be as a man who is paid to work for you, as one who is traveling from place to place, until the Year of Jubilee.
25.41: Then he will leave you, he and his children, that he may return to the land of his fathers.
25.42: For I brought them out of the land of Egypt as My servants. They are not to be sold as a servant.
25.43: Do not make it hard for him, but fear your God.
25.44: Those men and women you may have who are sold as servants will be from the nations around you.
25.45: You may buy from among the children of the strangers who live among you, and from their families that are with you and were born in your land. You may own them.
25.46: You may give them to your children after you, to receive as their own. You can have them as servants forever. But do not make it hard for your brothers, the people of Israel.
25.47: ‘Now a stranger or one visiting you may become rich. And your brother may become so poor that he sells himself to a stranger living among you, or to the children of a stranger’s family.
25.48: Then he may be made free after he has been sold. One of his brothers may pay the price to free him.
25.49: His father’s brother, the son of his father’s brother, or one of his own family may pay the price to free him. Or if he becomes rich he may pay the price himself.
25.50: With the one who bought him he will add the years from the year he sold himself until the Year of Jubilee. The price for him to be set free will be decided upon by the number of years. The time he was with the man who owned him will be as that of a man paid to work for him.
25.51: If there are still many years, he will return a part of the price which was given for him.
25.52: If there is only a few years until the Year of Jubilee, he will decide upon the amount of money with his owner. He should pay the price to be set free, decided upon by the number of years.
25.53: He will be like a man paid to work for him year by year. Make sure his owner does not make it hard for him.
25.54: Even if the price is not paid for him in this way, he will go free in the Year of Jubilee, he and his children.
25.55: Because the people of Israel are My servants. They are My servants whom I brought out of the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.

26.1: ‘Do not make gods for yourselves. Do not set up for yourselves something to look like a god or a holy object. Do not set up something cut from stone in your land to bow down to. For I am the Lord your God.
26.2: Keep My Days of Rest and honor My holy place. I am the Lord.
26.3: If you live by My Laws and do what I say,
26.4: I will give you rain at the right time. So the land will give its food and the trees will give their fruit.
26.5: The crushing of your grain will last until the grapes are gathered. The grape gathering will last until the seeds are planted. You will eat your food until you are full, and be safe living in your land.
26.6: I will give peace in the land. You will lie down and no one will make you afraid. I will make the land free from the danger of wild animals. And no sword will move through your land.
26.7: You will go after those who hate you, and they will fall in front of you by the sword.
26.8: Five of you will go after a hundred. A hundred of you will go after ten thousand. And those who hate you will fall in front of you by the sword.
26.9: I will care for you and give you many children. I will keep My agreement with you.
26.10: You will eat last year’s food, and use it all because you will have new.
26.11: I will make My home among you. My soul will not turn away from you.
26.12: I will walk among you and be your God. And you will be My people.
26.13: I am the Lord your God Who brought you out of the land of Egypt so you would not be their servants. I have broken loose the heavy load from your back and made you walk straight.
26.14: ‘But if you do not obey Me and do not do all I say,
26.15: if you turn away from My Laws and do not want to do what I tell you to do, and do not do it, and so break My agreement,
26.16: I will do this to you: I will bring upon you much fear, disease that destroys, and sickness that will waste away the eyes and make the body weak. You will plant your seeds for nothing, for those who hate you will eat it.
26.17: I will turn against you so you will fall in front of those who fight you. Those who hate you will rule over you. You will run away when no one is coming after you.
26.18: If after all of these things you still do not obey Me, I will punish you seven times more for your sins.
26.19: I will break the pride you have of your power. I will make your sky like iron and your earth like brass.
26.20: You will use your strength for nothing. For your land will not give food, and the trees of the land will not give fruit.
26.21: ‘If you act against Me and will not obey Me, I will bring you seven times more trouble than your sins.
26.22: I will let the wild animals loose among you. They will rob you of your children and destroy your cattle. They will make you few in number, so that your roads will be empty.
26.23: ‘If after these things you do not turn to Me, but still go against Me,
26.24: then I will go against you. I Myself will punish you seven times for your sins.
26.25: I will bring a sword upon you that will punish you for breaking the agreement. I will send disease among you when you gather together in your cities. So you will be given into the hands of those who hate you.
26.26: When I take away your bread of life, ten women will make your bread in one stove. They will give out your bread by weight. And you will eat it and not be filled.
26.27: ‘If you still do not obey Me after all this, but go against Me,
26.28: then I will go against you with anger. I Myself will punish you seven times for your sins.
26.29: You will eat the flesh of your sons and daughters.
26.30: I will destroy your high places and cut down your altars of special perfume. I will throw your dead bodies on what is left of your gods. My soul will hate you.
26.31: I will destroy your cities also, and your holy places. I will not smell your pleasing smells.
26.32: I will destroy the land, so those living in it who hate you will be filled with fear because of it.
26.33: I will divide you among the nations and send the sword after you. Your land will be destroyed and your cities a waste.
26.34: ‘Then the land will be like new because of its Days of Rest while it lies waste and you are in the land of those who hate you. Then the land will rest and have new life because of the Days of Rest.
26.35: As long as it lies waste it will have the rest it did not have on your Days of Rest, while you were living in it.
26.36: Of those of you who are left in the lands of those who hate you, I will make their hearts weak. The sound of a leaf blown by the wind will make them run away even when no one is going after them. They will run away as if it were a sword, and they will fall.
26.37: They will fall over each other as if running from the sword, when no one is going after them. You will have no strength to stand up in front of those who hate you.
26.38: You will die among the nations. The land of those who hate you will eat you up.
26.39: So those of you who are left will waste away in the lands of those who hate you, because of their sins. Also because of the sins of their fathers, they will waste away with them.
26.40: ‘If they tell their sins and the sins of their fathers which they did when they were not faithful to Me and were against Me with anger,
26.41: (I also was angry with them and brought them into the land of those who hate them) if their sinful heart loses its pride and they are willing to turn away from their sin,
26.42: I will remember My agreement with Jacob, My agreement with Isaac, and My agreement with Abraham. And I will remember the land.
26.43: But the land will be left behind them and become better with its Days of Rest while it lies empty without them. During this time they will turn away from their sin because they had not done what I told them to do and their soul hated My Laws.
26.44: Yet even when they are in the land of those who hate them, I will not turn away from them. I will not hate them enough to destroy them and break My agreement with them. For I am the Lord their God.
26.45: But because of them I will remember the agreement with their fathers, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt in the eyes of the nations, to be their God. I am the Lord.’”
26.46: These are the Laws which the Lord made between Himself and the people of Israel through Moses at Mount Sinai.

27.1: Then the Lord said to Moses,
27.2: “Say to the sons of Israel, ‘When a man makes a special promise, you will decide upon the worth of this person for the Lord.
27.3: The price you put on a man from twenty to sixty years old will be fifty pieces of silver, by the weight of the holy place.
27.4: For a woman it will be thirty pieces of silver.
27.5: For a male from five to twenty years old it will be twenty pieces of silver. For a woman it will be ten pieces of silver.
27.6: Your price for a child from one month to five years old will be five pieces of silver for the boy, and three pieces of silver for the girl.
27.7: Your price for a person sixty years old and older will be fifteen pieces of silver for the man, and ten pieces of silver for the woman.
27.8: But if the person is too poor to pay your price, he will be brought to the religious leader. The religious leader will decide the worth of the person by how much he who made the promise is able to pay.
27.9: ‘If it is a kind of animal which men give as a gift to the Lord, any such animal that is given to the Lord will be holy.
27.10: He must not have another animal take its place, good for bad or bad for good. If he does trade one animal for another, then both animals will become holy.
27.11: But if the animal is unclean and not the kind which men give to the Lord, then he will bring the animal to the religious leader.
27.12: The religious leader will decide if it is good or bad. Whatever price the religious leader puts on it, so it will be.
27.13: If the man wants to buy it again, he will add a fifth to your price.
27.14: ‘When a man sets apart his house as holy to the Lord, the religious leader will decide if it is good or bad. Whatever price the religious leader puts on it, so it will be.
27.15: If the man who sets it apart wants to buy his house again, he will add one-fifth part to your price. Then it will be his.
27.16: ‘If a man sets apart to the Lord part of a field he owns, you will decide upon its price by the seed needed for it. Ten baskets of barley seed will be worth fifty pieces of silver.
27.17: If he sets apart his field during the Year of Jubilee, it will be worth your full price.
27.18: But if he sets apart his field after the Year of Jubilee, the religious leader will decide upon its worth by the years left until the next Year of Jubilee. It will be taken off your price.
27.19: If the man who sets it apart wants to buy his field again, he will add one-fifth part to your price. Then it will be his.
27.20: But if he does not want to buy the field again, or has sold the field to another man, it cannot be bought again.
27.21: And when the field becomes free in the Jubilee, it will be holy to the Lord, like a field set apart. It will belong to the religious leader.
27.22: If a man sets apart to the Lord a field he has bought, which is not a part of the land he was given by his father,
27.23: the religious leader will decide its worth until the Year of Jubilee. The man will pay that amount on that day as holy to the Lord.
27.24: In the Year of Jubilee the field will return from him who bought it to the one who owned it first.
27.25: The price of silver used in the holy place will decide its worth. One piece of silver will be worth twenty small pieces of money.
27.26: ‘But no man may set apart a first-born of the animals. A first-born of the cattle or the flock belongs to the Lord.
27.27: If it is an animal that is unclean, he will buy it again by paying your price and one-fifth part added to it. If it is not bought again, then it will be sold for your price.
27.28: ‘But nothing that a man sets apart to the Lord of all he has, of man or animal or his own land, will be sold or bought. Everything that has been set apart is most holy to the Lord.
27.29: No person who has been set apart to be destroyed from among men can be paid for. He must be put to death.
27.30: ‘The tenth part of all the land, of the seed of the land or of the fruit of the tree, is the Lord’s. It is holy to the Lord.
27.31: If a man wants to buy any of the tenth part that belongs to the Lord, he will add one-fifth part to its price.
27.32: And every tenth animal of the cattle or flock, whatever passes under the shepherd’s stick, the tenth one will be holy to the Lord.
27.33: The man will not ask if it is good or bad, or trade it for something else. If he does trade it for something else, then both will become holy. He cannot buy them again.’”
27.34: These are the Laws the Lord gave Moses on Mount Sinai for the sons of Israel.
